Ticket #2079 "inserting an image into body tex..." was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last Comment in #2079: It appears 'choose a picture' widget is completely broken (not just when trying to add a picture to styled content.text).

Merging with #2179 which is the same story w/ more details.

Hi
If you could prioritize this ticket as important to be able to add and amend images in existing sports pages.
Cheers, Zara
Looking at this family of issues now.
This is going to be my weekend read: http://niichavo.wordpress.com/2009/01/06/contenteditable-div-cursor-position/
update?

This is a horrible timesink. Page editor is close to unacceptable in IE, especially when trying to deal with rich elements. It has quite a few browser hacks (instead of feature hacks), but I'm afraid it never worked perfectly on IE. I'd advise to use IE for just very basic text editing stuff and fall back for firefox for anything like this. The long term solution would be to cut down page editor features to half and code that reliably and/or have strict browser requirements.

Zara, we have spent quite a bit of time investigated this issue and the prognosis is not terribly good.

Internet Explorer has always been somewhat problematic for dealing with rich text editing. While it is fine for doing simple editing tasks, some things just do not work as well as we would like in IE. 

Getting picture deletion and uploading working properly in IE is likely to require a considerable amount of developer effort.

Our best advise (and I realise that this is suboptimal for you), is to fall back to Firefox for anything but the more simple editing tasks. If it is possible, we strongly recommend installing Firefox onto your PC.

Ticket #2208 "Inserting pictures into text" was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last comment in ticket #2208: Hi

I have tried to insert a picture into a text box (the body section) but it doesn't appear - we are using Internet Explorer.

It was on this page:
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/get-involved/education/international-inspiration/what-is-international-inspiration/index.php

Can you help?

thanks

Mairi

Ticket #1806 "Recurring problem" was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last comment in ticket #1806: It looks remarkably similar to #2178

Hi Danny

Thanks for this. I have Firefox and cvan work in that, but going forward when we have a bigger team and volunteers, they won't all have f/fox and that could cause issues at gametime. Could I get a quote/ timescale of how long it would take to fix this in IE?

Thanks, Zara
Jamie, over to you for this. I am assuming she doesn't actually mean games time itself. Or maybe she is not aware that delta tre are taking over before the games.

Given how tricky this will be to fix, it may actually make more sense to look at changing the templates where Zara is trying to assign images and seeing if we can use a <content:picture> container instead.

In short the inline images/editing stuff only has so much mileage and we could just be on a fruitless struggle trying to resolve it (the real answer is probably to re-write the page editor / rich text editor from the ground up, but as that isn't realistically going to happen this year, putting a time against this ticket to do that is rather pointless. In theory if we could get Michael in for a months he possible could rewrite it, but then I expect we'd end up with another two dozen new issues as a result of doing that).

Looking at the templates and how we could restructure them so we could use a <content:picture> container is however realistic, although a bit open ended / more a design issue.

Zara, apologies for taking so long to get back to you on this one, but this is a somewhat intractable problem, without a realistic timescale. 

However, there is another solution which we haven't mentioned: refactoring the page template so that instead of inline images, we place image containers in specific locations on the page. This may even be a better solution than allowing inline images if you are likely to have more people entering content over the next 12 months, because it enforces layout more than adding images inline on an ad hoc basis.

So, to summarize, the options are:

1. Use Firefox;

2. Refactor templates so that there are more pre-defined slots for image containers.
Zara, we have spent 2+ days on this over the last several months (mostly back in December/January). I am going to mark this as solved with one billable day on it, if that is OK with you.
But I don’t think it is actually working, is it?
No. That is correct.
Can you work with Tom on a more satisfying resolution (rather than ignoring the problem)? ☺
Marking as closed.
Added to March retainer.

Hi Liz, just had a quick call with Tom. Let's discuss when you are ready.
Can we set a time of a call? Maybe tomorrow morning or later today?

The two sections are:
- Planning - http://www.london2012.com/planning/
- Young Leaders - http://www.london2012.com/young-leaders/

These are completely self-contained and can almost certainly co-exist happily on sub-domains.

The London2012 dropdown I am less sure about. So far as I can see, it doesn't appear on Getset, tickets or Shop. Where do you need it other than on Festival?

Quick follow up: I have just heard from Kirsten who has confirmed that the web01/02/03 infrastructure will be in place for game time, so there is no reason that we cannot continue to host Planning and Young Leaders on the current servers on sub-domains. 

The swap over from e.g. http://www.london2012.com/planning/ to  http://pdt.london2012.com/ can probably happen at any time between now and games time, once the new sub-domains have been set up to point at the correct end point and the appropriate config file has been updated, although we will have to make some changes to the publication engine on the CMS to ensure that the two sections use the correct domain as the base href for links.

Thanks, Danny. So what are the next steps? Kirsten asked me to get Kitsite to ‘tell her where to point to’ – is that something we can just tell her? Apologies for being a bit confused as to what I should ask to do next! I think it does make sense to make the switch prior to the Games (essentially asap).

The first step is to point the new sub-domains at the existing web0x infrastructure as used by www.london2012.com &c.

Once that is done we can liaise with BT to update the apache config to accommodate the new sub-domains.
Liz, just picking this up again. Do you know if Kirsten has been briefed yet about creating DNS entries for the rump sub-domains and pointing them at the web0x servers?

I know we gave her a list of things ... am not sure where she has gotten to with it.

Tom can you follow-up?

We do need to start planning a few things (e.g. the website checker)...

Hi Andy,

The short answer is yes we can,

But it may be worth thinking whether it would it be OK to let those urls naturally drop out of Google's index and then get re-indexed, as we are sending a proper 404 page not found headers for them. Obviously if these are inbound links from other sites (rather than just links in Googles site index) then that is another matter and we probably do need to match them up.

The one downside to bulk redirects like this is the server load, as every request will need to first run a check to see if it matches any of those redirects, this may seem insignificant at first, but if we ended up with a couple of thousand redirects that could in turn end up adding a significant load to each request especially which when multiplied up by millions of requests 

If the URL follow a pattern ie. the section name has changed or if any pages in /volunteering should now go to the /volunteer hub we may be able to write a single wildcard redirect which would be more efficient.

So in short, yes we can, if it's external urls from other sites we should (and can we pattern match any of them en-mass?). But if this is just a case of cleaning up Google index it may be better to let Google's indexer go about it's business and drop the old urls and reindex the new ones next time it spiders the site, rather than trying to force anything and clogging up each request with hundreds of redirect lookups (which may grow over time).

Jamie

Andy, let us know if you want us to redirect these (and send us the file) or if you think it's OK to let them fall out of Google index and get re indexed naturally.

Jamie

Jamie,

I’ve asked David to take a look at this. Many of these pages are being linked to from around the web and, if we can come up with a few simple wildcard rules, it’d be good to use these links to build search status rather than just leave them as 404s. I’ll update you as soon as I can.

Thanks, Andy

In that case, it makes absolute sense to redirect them..

See if you can sport an obvious patterns, but don't' worry too much, we can turn a two column Excel doc into a bunch of redirect rules fairly easily.

Have a good weekend

Jamie

Hi Jamie,

We’ve decided the way we’d like to handle this is to 301 redirect 404s up the relevant hub page - so a missing news article would go to the news landing page, and a missing link to something in volunteering would go to the volunteering landing page. The only exception would be where we’ve changed the name of a section, in which case we should obviously redirect to the page’s new location.

Is this achieveable?

Regards,
Andy
Hi Jamie, any update on this?  (As you can probably tell, I'll doing a trawl of my open tickets!)
Reassign to Kieran?
Marking as a priority for this week. To do: get back to Andy on his comment from Feb-17.

Have amended the name of this ticket.
Am attaching proposal for the above, for discussion at this afternoon's mtg.
Kieran
Passed to David Marshall for review. I’ll submit consolidated feedback and schedule a call once his comments are in.

Hi guys,

Realise I've been a bit slow on this. Response from David on the 404 proposal is as follows:

"I have included an export of your Google crawl results and unfortunately we are talking about more like 10,000 URL than 300. This will have a significant impact on how this is approached. I think we need to identify wildcards that would forward with a 301 to some new or higher level directory. I am assuming that most of these 10,000 URL are the result of some old URL structure change where no appropriate 301s where put in place when the changes were rolled out. 

The primary strategy is to redirect as many of these 404 to the appropriate pages using 301 redirects. The secondary strategy would be to have a smart 404 page for the 404 not caught by our rule set that uses search to provide relevant links to what the user is probably looking for. This smart 404 page is very much (OPTIONAL) and will not be necessary if we think we can catch most of the 404 with a rule set."

(I've attached the list of 404s.)

Could you take a look and tweak your proposal accordingly - hopefully you'll be able to spot a pattern in the 404 so that rules can be used for the redirects.

I've not commented on the sitemap part of the document as we're handling that elsewhere now.

Thanks,
Andy
Hi, realise you're flat out at the moment, but could you let me know when you'll be able to take a look at this?

I propose the following:
  1. 403's should yield the error page.
  2. For the big list of 404's: Write a script to investigate them. Many will simply be pages which have been moved [A], but still linked-to from elsewhere on the internet. Many might be broken links [B] within london2012.com. [A] we can fix by writing a lookup-table in 404.php, which redirects to a sensible page. [B] we can fix by republishing pages with stale links.

Estimate:
 (1.) 0.5 day.
 (2.) Investigation: 1 day, Fixing [A] 1 day. Fixing [2] 1 day.

Total: 3.5 days.

Hi Jamie,

I'm keen to progress this one please - especially given the sudden and unexplained jump in inbound links that result in a 404. Could you let me know when you'll be able to take a look?

Cheers,
Andy

Andy, can you let me know: do you have a more up-to-date version of this csv report?
I ask because there have been a few changes made since this report was generated, so I'm keen to avoid fixing things that have already been fixed!
Thanks in advance,
Kieran

Hi Kieran,

We think the huge increase in 404s we spotted a few weeks ago was due to an issue with the Googlebot as many of the URLs we checked turned out to be fine, and the number reported has now dropped. However, we're still seeing over 5,000 404s. Some will be due to incorrect links from other sites, but many will be due to moved and/or renamed sections and pages on the site. We'd like to 301 as many of these to the correct page as we can (using mod-rewrite rules?) and then implement the smart 404 handling we've discussed previously.

I've attached a couple of current reports from Google Webmaster Tools. One contains all the 404s Google has identified, and the other lists the sources of these errors.

Tom was going to spend some time looking at the 404s list today to try to spot patterns where we've obviously moved or renamed a lot of content. These would be prime candidates for a generic 301 rule. If you're going to do this I'll ask him not to bother.

Btw, could you add him to this ticket please?

Thanks,
Andy

Hi Andy,
I will be looking at these, so Tom can ignore for the moment.
Thanks,
Kieran

Hi Kieran,

Could you let me know where you've got to with this so I can update our SEO guy?

Cheers,
Andy

Hi Andy,
I have been investigating the long list of 404s.
Basically, I have been trying to come up with a sensible algorithm to map as many as possible to "real pages" on the website.
One such strategy is to work UP the hierarchy and serve the first page that exists.
So for example, when presented with:
  /blog/2011/03/Not/Found/index.php
we would check for:
   /blog/2011/03/Not/Found/index.php
   /blog/2011/03/Not/index.php
   /blog/2011/03/index.php (at which point we would find that this exists, and we would redirect the user to this page).

This works well in a lot of cases. However, there are many situations in which it /doesn't/ work particularly well.
For example., there are many inbound links to:
  /about/path/to/page.php
which should really be:
  /about-us/path/to/page.php

The algorithm above will give us (rather unsatisfactorily) "/index.php".

So, I'm currently in the process of looking for more such paths, and trying to fine-tune the algorithm accordingly.

I should have some more information by midday tomorrow but - of course - please ask if you have any questions.

Kind regards,
Kieran

Hi Kieran,

Sounds like you're making good progress. I think there are entire sections that have been renamed in the past so you can probably identify these and write mod_rewrite rules to handle them (assuming this is the approach you're taking), and then create a generic rule like the one you've suggested above for other missing pages.

Cheers,
Andy

Hi Andy, I have now done the following:

1. I've attached two files, one showing the requests that I managed to match, the other showing the ones that I couldn't. Could you look at both of these and have a think about whether the matches in match.csv look sensible, and also whether there is a rule that could be used to match any more requests in "nomatch.csv".

 2. I've amended the 404 page on staging such that it tries to use my algorithm to find a suitable page to serve. So, for example,
  http://vip_staging_locog_www.london2012.com/blog/2011/01/made-up-pagename.php
redirects to:
  http://vip_staging_locog_www.london2012.com/blog/2011/01/index.php
Another example:
  http://vip_staging_locog_www.london2012.com/visiting/getting-to-the-games/made-up-section/
redirects to:
  http://vip_staging_locog_www.london2012.com/visiting/getting-to-the-games/index.php

I have a couple more amendments to make to the 404 page, to link to a search page with a suitable search term, but I hope there is enough here for you to look at, and comment on?

The algorithm is (roughly).
Take path, p.
Replace /games/venues/games/ with /games/
Replace /about/ with /about-us/
Replace /sports/olympic/ with /games/olympic-sports/
Replace /sports/ with /games/
Replace /about-this-website/about-this-website/ with /about-this-website/
Replace /about-this-website/get-involved/ with /get-involved/

Look at p, "path/to/some/page.php"
Does "path/to/some/page.php" exist? if so, use it
Does "path/to/some/index.php" exist? if so, use it
Does "path/to/index.php" exist? if so, use it
Does "path/index.php" exist? if so, use it

There's also a tiny bit of magic to look for archived news stories.

Kieran

Hi Kieran,

The stuff in the nomatch file looks reasonable. In the match file:

1. There are a bunch of pages for /blog/includes/blog/... which would work better if we could strip out the initial /blog/includes.

2. There are a few entries for /games/olympic-sport-competition-schedule/index.php which would ideally redirect to http://www.london2012.com/olympic-schedule.

3. There’s a list of sports pages that we should be able to link. E.g. /games/olympic-sports/games/olympic-sports/archery.php should go to /archery.

Those are the only ones that jump out – although I’ve only briefly scrolled through.

You’ve mentioned the 404 page with the search suggestion – when would this be displayed? If we’re redirecting further up the site hierarchy won’t all dead URLs be catered for, even if they ultimately display the homepage? Or were you planning on limiting the number of jumps up the hierarchy a user is taken?

Cheers,
Andy

Re. how many levels to jump up the hierarchy: this is up to you (and/or David) really.
We can, of course, go all the way to the top level but then again it might more sense to display a link to:
 "Click here to search for 'new volleyball arena""
if you try to visit (for example) http://www.london2012.com/new-volleyball-arena.

We'd be happy to go all the way up, which I assume would be simpler for you too.

Where and how can we test this?

Right, I've implemented your suggestions:

> We'd be happy to go all the way up
The "search" algorithm now goes "all the way up" - i.e. in the last resort, it will return the homepage.

> 1. There are a bunch of pages for /blog/includes/blog/... 
Done

> 2. There are a few entries for /games/olympic-sport-competition-schedule/index.php ...
Done

> 3. ... /games/olympic-sports/games/olympic-sports/archery.php should go to /archery.
Done

This behaviour can all be previewed on the staging server, for example:
  http://vip_staging_locog_www.london2012.com/blog/includes/blog/2008/12/?day=03
will redirect you to:
  http://vip_staging_locog_www.london2012.com/blog/2008/12/index.php

I am attaching the revised versions of "match29.csv" and "no-match29.csv" ("29" reflecting today's date).


Kieran

I'm attaching the results of my tests /against the staging server/.
Kieran
Kieran, can you give us an "Actual days" update on this and can you remember where we are with it? It would be good to get this closed with some time against it if at all possible.

Hi Kieran,

First of all, huge apologies I've not managed to find time to look at this in over a month! I've just been having a play and it appears to work perfectly in staging.

Before I raise this with technology to get the implementation planning under way, could I check whether the 'all the way up' functionality could be turned off for a period every few weeks to run automated checks for actual broken links on the site, or whether once it's implemented we're masking these forever more?

Also, if we were able to turn this off, would the section redirect rules you've put in place to manage sections we've moved or renamed also get disabled? (No is the answer I'm hoping for!)

Thanks,
Andy

I'm not sure what you need to do, re. implementation planning.
Basically, this functionality can - as you ask - be switched on/off in an instant, whenever you're ready, and on an ad-hoc basis.
> would the section redirect rules ...
If you're referring to the short urls, seo-paths, and ad-hoc htaccess rules the answer is - as you hope for - "No".
Kieran

Hi Kieran,

With regards to the last point - I meant can the 404 redirecting be turned off whilst keeping rules such as these in place:
Replace /games/venues/games/ with /games/
Replace /about/ with /about-us/
Replace /sports/olympic/ with /games/olympic-sports/
Replace /sports/ with /games/
Replace /about-this-website/about-this-website/ with /about-this-website/
Replace /about-this-website/get-involved/ with /get-involved/

That is, the redirects we have to put in place when we move or rename a section. These may be the htaccess rules you've mentioned - is that right?

In terms of implementation planning, I just need to advise technology and agree a date to turn it on.

Thanks,
Andy
Ah, in which case the answer is "'No', BUT ... given a bit of time this afternoon, 'Yes'".
Hold fire with that - I have some other bits I need to ask you - just flat out on something else right now!

Hi Kieran,

It appears we have had a bit of a misunderstand on this. (By 'we', I mean me and David.) Whilst I thought it was clear what we had asked you to do, in checking the implementation of it he has raised a concern about automatically redirecting all links that 404. His response is below. Are you able to run these reports? I've attached the latest extract from Google Analytics.

Thanks,
Andy 

David's email:
I've spent a lot of time researching this today but prior to making a final recommendation I'm wondering if it would be possible to get the MATCH & NOMATCH csv files for the following three scenarios:

1. Specific redirect rules only (no-hops)
2. Specific redirect rules plus one-hop
3. Specific redirect rules plus two-hops

If we don't gain a lot by adding the the extra hops I recommend that we just go with the specific redirect rules (OPTION 1). If there are significant gains in adding the one-hop but marginal gains in adding the second hop than I think we should go for the one-hop (OPTION 2). If there are significant gains from adding two-hops over the one-hop I think we should go for two-hops (OPTION 2) but don't recommend going over two hops.

Can I check what you mean by "hops"?

Am I correct in thinking that "one hop only" means that:

 /d1/d2/d3/non-existent-file.php

would be redirected to:

 /d1/d2/d3/

if that folder exists (and it has an index.php) BUT that if that folder
/didn't/ exist, we would serve a 404, rather than checking for /d1/d2/ or
/d1/ ?

Thanks,

Kieran

Hi Kieran – yes, that’s exactly it.

Andy
Andy, have we got a final recommendation from David on which option we are going for?
No, I’m waiting for the reports I requested from Kieran on the 25th. In fact I’d just asked Tom to mention this when you speak later.

Andy, I should have picked this up earlier, but those "reports" referred to earlier are not trivial to produce. The last lot took several hours to massage. We can do the same again, but I think we are getting quite close to the 3.5 days I think we have already agreed for this ticket. Assuming this is the last round of reports, would it be acceptable for us to bump this ticket up to 4 days?
Sure – go for it.

Hi Andy,
See attached.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Kieran

Hi Kieran,

I don't think this is what I'm after. I was expecting 3 reports; one for each of the scenarios listed above. Which scenario does this relate to? Can I get the other reports?

Thanks,
Andy
Andy, are we proceeding with this ticket or should I close it? Many thanks.
Andy, can you give me an update on this one?

Danny, apologies for not getting back to you. Given we launch the GTW in a few weeks I’m going to ask you to close this piece of work.

Thanks,
Andy
Closing. total: 4 days (billed to retainer).
Added to March retainer.

description: Example document: https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/olympic-route-network/tros/wap-togv14-made-tro.pdf
subject: Documents apparently not publishing

comments.value: Example document: https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/preview/olympic-route-network/tros/wap-togv14-made-tro.pdf

The documents are publishing, but there is a redirect in place on the live site that redirects all requests for PDFs in the /olympic-route-network/ folder to the /orn/ folder.

I believe this was done as an expedient, because a large number of links were mistakenly made in the new pages to documents that were still in the old folder (documents which are all replicated in the new folder).

The upshot is that no new documents should be placed in the old /olympic-route-network/ folder, but should be placed in the /orn/ folder instead.

If you do this, your problem will go away.

(the /olympic-route-network/ should probably be removed, to avoid confusion).

It's showing for me, could it be the wrong url you were looking at? (/olympic-route-network/ is the old section ?)
http://www.london2012.com/orn/tros/wap-togv14-made-tro.pdf

NOT PROTECTIVELY MARKED 

 

I moved the files following Danny's comment - although strangely didn't
change the links on the page itself. So not sure why they now work!
Either way, they do. 

 

Danny - if you deleted the old folder, wouldn't all the existing links
to pdfs need updating on the pages? 

 

Thanks anyway.

Simon
Simon, you are quite correct. Actually deleting the files would cause problems. However removing the old folder from the CMS interface might reduce confusion.

NOT PROTECTIVELY MARKED 

 

To be honest Danny, we left it there on the understanding that we should
add any new pdf downloads to the old folder, but it seems like we should
add new pdfs to the new folder, which is fine, so long as we know. It
wasn't confusion this end, just a misunderstanding as to which folder
(new or old) we stuck them in. Going forward we'll add them to the new
folder. Bear in mind that we're not planning for this microsite to exist
for much longer.
Marking as solved.

Resolved, but trying to work out what happened. From Kieran: "I've retrieved the list of command that Katherine carried out, and she seems to be doing nothing suspicious. I would be very keen to discover her operating system (presumably Windows?), and browser version, if possible?"

Hi,

She’s said it’s Firefox 3.6.3

Thanks

Is this the same as other users? (you, for example?)
Thanks,
Kieran

Yep, same as mine!

Thanks

I have examined the entire save-log and it appears that "saving an empty page" has occurred three times in the past 2 years.

	[2011-04-27 10:54:03,400] [zara.rabinowicz@new2012] making-it-happen/index.php
	[2012-02-10 11:50:00,913] [Katherine.Donnelly@new2012] get-involved/local-leaders/garden-for-the-games/index.php
	[2012-03-16 18:49:25,936] [Katherine.Donnelly@new2012] get-involved/local-leaders/index.php

Obviously the two recent ones were both Katherine. I'm wondering whether there's something distinct about the way that she uses the CMS.
She's using the same Firefox version as everyone else, I gather. I'm wondering whether there is anything else she might be doing differently.
For example, I'm wondering whether she might be - on occasion - double-clicking rather than single-clicking. Of course this shouldn't cause a problem, but it might be that it does - in which case we should try to fix it if possible.
Or is there anything else that's obviously different about her setup? E.g. she is using a tablet/touchpad/trackpad rather than a mouse, or something?

Apologies for not having any concrete suggestions. Any evidence you can gather - if possible - would be very helpful.

Thanks in advance,

Kieran

Hi Kieran,

I’m not aware of having done anything different to what I normally do when I’m on there...and I’m not using a tablet or trackpad I’m afraid. I’m usually really careful about saving everything after I’ve made a change, so whatever happened here is a total mystery.

Sorry I can’t be more help.

Thanks,
Kat

Kat,
Thanks for replying.
Unless the issue can be reproduced, it is very tricky for us to find the problem and/or implement a solution. If this happens again, please let us know immediately.
Actually, one thought: Did it happen after you had pasted some content from an external application? Specifically I'm thinking of Word/Excel, but it might also be that content copied from your email client, or webmail/other caused some kind of an issue. I know it's almost a week ago now but is there anything you can remember copying/pasting from another application when editing that page?
Thanks in advance,
Kieran

Hi Kieran,

Sorry I don’t have a better explanation, but all I did on that page was swap the Line the Streets promo image for a newer version, save, preview and exit.

In any case, I usually copy &paste any copy into notepad before putting it into CMS. I may have copied & pasted from word on another occasion as an oversight, but I’m almost 100% sure I didn’t when this happened. Like I said, it was just a simple image swap.

Sorry I can’t give you more info than that

Best,
Kat
OK. I am going to close this ticket now. It sounds like this problem is a relatively rare event, which is going to be hard to reproduce, but please do let us know if it happens again.

description: Larry from Liberty is planning to commission an interactive map for their website. He will contact us at some point for more advice on how to incorporate it into the site, probably under http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/about/.
subject: New map for Liberty website

comments.value: Larry from Liberty is planning to commission an interactive map for their website. He will contact us at some point for more advice on how to incorporate it into the site, probably under http://www.liberty-human-rights.org.uk/about/.

He has decided to do a google map. So his current requirements are for a new template based on their standard content template, but with a placeholder to allow him to embed some map code, to be placed in their About section. He will email us with more details in due course.

description:
From: Steven Hughes <Steven.hughes@london2012.com>

I’m after a bit of advice ... on this page of the Learning Legacy
website (http://learninglegacy.london2012.com/themes/sustainability/research-summaries.php),
I need to link to a document which is on an external site. The trouble
that I am having is that as the page is set up as a publication list
and I am unable to add a group (when using page editor) in order to
link directly to the external site.

As this is not a branded London 2012 document we don’t want this paper
to site on the LL site, we only want to link to it BUT it does need to
site under the sustainability/research summary theme.

Is there anyway around this? Any advice welcome.

Someone has found a bug with the torchbearer search. It appears the
search fails if the TB has a hyphen in their name. There’s one example
in the email below, and I’ve also verified it’s a problem with ‘Keia
Wardman Wardman-trerise’.

From: Sarah Cottier

Sue Holland-Leavans – if you type in Sue she is on the second page of
Sues however if you type sue Holland – her name comes up in the
dropdown box but then if you click on her name it says no results
found?

Hi,
I'm currently trying to migrate outstanding images on london2012.com via our Media Manager system in Getty using the xml here:
https://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/api/custom/gtw-photos?apiKey=p5tN1FrFOgcRdN4YXGAnpg

There doesn't appear to be a way to filter via date, which would be a massive help. Do you know if this is possible of if the data can be exported into a format which allows sorting or searching?
Many thanks indeed,
Jacob

<hr width="100%">
The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Limited
A company registered in England and Wales with its registered office at One Churchill Place, Canary Wharf, London E14 5LN and registered number 05267819

E-mail.
             
Nothing in this message or its attachments is intended to create legal relations between us unless there is an express statement creating such relations or this message contains an authorised purchase order.
                                     
Internet communications cannot be guaranteed to be timely secure, error or virus-free. The sender does not accept liability for any errors or omissions.

http://www.london2012.com
<hr width="100%">

Hi Jacob,
Unless I misunderstand your question, the data currently IS exported in a format that allows sorting/searching.
i.e. it currently contains elements like:
  <page id="2684795" path="photos/2010/1/jonathan-edwards-at-the-london-2012-roadshow-in-stafford-67369.php" date="25 Jan 2010" name="Jonathan Edwards at the London 2012 Roadshow in Stafford"/>
i.e. they contain a "date" attribute (corresponding to the "creation date" in our CMS).
Is this not what you're looking for?
If we need to amend the api call, how would you like to filter by date? i.e. would you need to specify a from/to creation-date?
Thanks,
Kieran

Thanks Kieran,
The date is what I’m looking for but I want to be able to only look for content created since the end of November 2011 and there’s no way (that I can see) in the attached list to sort the data in the way, not in that format anyway??
Many thanks,
Jacob

I can change the date so that it is in the following format:

 YYYYMMDD

(e.g. "20100527").

Would this help?
But would the content then be listed in date order? That’s the issue really.

Ok, the data is now order by creation-date.
In some circumstances this does not correspond with the path in the CMS.
For example:

<page id="2005842" path="photos/2008/11/aquatics-centre-at-night-60949.php"
date="6 Mar 2009" name="Aquatics Centre at night"/>

I can only presume that this is the result of pages being retrospectively
created (i.e. created after the date to which they relate). The important
thing, from your point of view, is that the data is now ordered by the date
that appears in @date attribute.

Please let me know whether this is as required.

Kind regards,

Kieran

This is great. Many thanks indeed.
Jacob
Closing ticket

comments.value:
This is a follow-up to your previous request #7059 "Redirect details request"

Hi Jamie,
Hope you’re well. Just wanted to pick this conversation back up from a month or so back.
Is it possible to have the redirect url’s and ‘short’ SEO URL’S exported into doc’s – possibly excel – please?
This would be a real help.
Many thanks,
Jacob

From: Jamie Unwin [mailto:notifications-support@postcms.zendesk.com]
Sent: 19 January 2012 15:45
To: Jacob Melton
Subject: [PostCMS support] Re: Redirect details request
Marking as high.

Hi Jacob,

As you're aware, there are three broad types of redirection/rewriting that
are used on the london2012.com site.

SEO-friendly rewrites: All pages on the site have a "canonical" path (a
path which contains 0 or more section names, followed by a filename [with a
.php extension]). As these are not particularly SEO-friendly, pages can
also be assigned an SEO-path. The client is NOT served a redirect, the path
is rewritten on the server. These are contained in SEO.csv, attached.

"Marketing" redirects: Paths that are shortened for ease-of-remembering
(e.g. for advertising campaigns). A permanent redirect is served. These are
contained in Marketing.csv, attached. Note that a few of these actually
redirect to external sites.

Ad-hoc redirects/rewrites: Links/paths that have been circulated/published
erroneously. Plus some paths that have deliberately been changed, but that
might have been extensively linked to. Plus some sensible redirects for
deleted pages.
Plus some url-rewrites to generate nicer urls for certain parts of the
website (for example /path/to/$id => /path/to/file.php/id=$id).
As these are more varied than the above rewrites, it is not really possible
to express them as simple "X gets mapped to Y" rules. Therefore I'm
attaching the relevant Apache configuration directives which you can use or
ignore, depending on requirements. If you need any more information about
these rules, please ask me.

Kind regards,

Kieran
Marking as solved.
Marking as high.

description:
Hi Rachael,



Please see below an outline of a new section of the site that we need to develop ahead of a launch in March,

If at all possible I'd like to arrange a kick-off call this week to discuss the below in further detail.



Thanks,



Tom



Our Torchbearers



We need to build a new part of the Olympic torch relay section of London2012.com in order to display our successful torchbearers.

This will consist of two new pages, a search page and a torchbearer page. Both pages should use the torch brand and be consistent with the existing torch section.



The search page



Visitors should be able to browse and search successful TBs by the following criteria:

*         Name (full name)

*         Torchbearing day and date "Day 1 - 19 May"

*         Torchbearing community



On running a search a list of TBs matching the selected criteria will be displayed. The list will display the following information for each TB:

*         Thumbnail photo or holding image if not available - (image will be square)

*         Full name

*         Torchbearing community

*         Torchbearing date

*         Link to view full details and nomination story



This will sit in an ordinary three columned page template, taking up the middle column.

The right hand side should have select includes - the usual 220x120 advert, related photos, and potentially a shop promo specifically for torch products.





Torchbearer Page



On choosing to view a TB's full details a page will be displayed with the following:

*         Thumbnail  photo - same as on search page

*         Full name

*         Age (tbc)

*         Torchbearing community

*         Torchbearing date

*         Home town

*         Nomination story

*         Chosen by (e.g. LOCOG, Coke, Samsung, Lloyds, BOA, etc)


The torchbearers will be announced on March 12th so we will be looking to complete this section ahead of then to launch at the same time.


Tom Price-Stephens
Assistant New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Ltd
Switchboard: +44 (0)20 3 2012  000 Extension: 381
Mobile: +44 7540 258 453
www.london2012.com
www.facebook.com/london2012
www.twitter.com/london2012
www.youtube.com/london2012

Up to 8,000 torchbearers in about 1,000 communities.

To be made available periodically (throughout March, April and May) as a CSV file.

Images for each torchbearer will be made available separately using a naming convention that will follow an ID in the CSV file.
Awaiting sample CSV file.
Proposed launch date: March 19.
Sample CSV file received.
Markup likely to be arriving from Cogapp today.

Danny, example profile images attached. These are all the images we have for the sample of 100 TBs we sent you. There are only 68, which is probably good as it allows us to test the display of the generic profile pic for those that don't have their own image.

Btw, we are going to allow TBs to request their images be deleted (but are not going to allow them to ask us to update or edit them, for resourcing reasons). Once we've launched will I be able to delete images myself via the CMS or will I need to ask you to do this?

Thanks,
Andy
Templates attached.

Comments on templates:
pageone.html - with js turned off the community dropdown will not appear
pageone-st2.html - with js turned off this is stage 2 of community search

Who? box - remove it. This is not wanted.

Related photos and videos should be exactly the same as on the corrent torch site, e.g. http://www.london2012.com/games/olympic-torch-relay/carrying-the-olympic-flame/

The new pages are going in the /carrying-the-olympic-flame sub-section (unless we hear differently).

As this will need quite a bit of testing, can it initially be built in the test directory? I only want to freeze the OTR section a few days before the announcement.

Ta,
Andy

Got it, Andy.

We may have something of a problem with "Communities". There are no "region" data in the CSV export from Roadrunner. Furthermore, there is more than one "Newport". 

We do have the Community Latitude and Community Longitude, but this might well require a non-trivial (i.e. time-consuming) mapping of community names to locations. 

Is there any way of getting regions exported out of Roadrunner? 

Failing that, could you give us a list of duplicate community names along with their region and longitude and latitude, as they appear in Roadrunner?

I’ve asked if this is possible Danny. If not, you should be able to figure it out based on day number rather than the lat/longs.

Andy
From Andy: "the URL we’ll use for the TB search page is /olympic-torch-relay-torchbearers. (This is the SEO URL, we may find something a bit shorter for marketing purposes.)"

From Tom: 

We are currently scrapping the torchbearer detail page.
 
On the torchbearer search page we will:
1.       Increase the image size to 77x77px

2.       Display the age and hometown fields (as well as community)

Danny, you will be able to pick up a near complete set of images from the following FTP server shortly.

URL: london2012.ftpstream.com
Login: tbphotos
Password: 9Weqazuy

We hope to process a few more tomorrow.
Finally! :)

Sent: 13 March 2012 16:00

Subject: [PostCMS support] Re: Basketball Arena webcam

As just discussed, we are expecting a list (I think quite a short one) of pages that are going to be renamed along with the pages that are going to link to the new torchbearers section. Because all of /games/olympic-torch-relay/ is currently locked on staging, any links from outside that section that link into the section could potentially be broken if they are published prematurely. 

The general rule is that any section that is locked on staging should be changed with extreme caution.

We also need to agree a timetable for launch this week.
